google_play_reviews.content: This app has worked very well in the past however over the last few updates it's been causing me problems with tethering not working until i open AFWall reapply rules. Using Galaxy S3 and LOS 14.1 with std kernel and LOS SU addon. I'm not 100% certain yet but i may have found the issue. Option in settings under Binaries/DNSProxy defaults to Auto should detect Android ver >= 4.3 but doesn't. Setting to "Enable DNS via netd" and tethering/DNS works again. Maybe LOS uses different UID for netd?

On version 3.0.3, still cannot make persistent notification icon go away. When enabled, persistent notification is a shield, when disabled it is a white ball. Developer says white ball is from Google. That may be, HOWEVER, neither existed in v2.9 and earlier, so persistent notification icon is due to some change within the app between 2.9 and 3.0. Based on other reviews, these changes should be reverted back to how the old version handled things. I'm glad I still have a copy of 2.9.
google_play_reviews.replyContent: I removed notification dot in the recent version. But active notification (on going) will stay until I find a workaround.

google_play_reviews.content: Ok after doing some digging it appears that Magisk needs to be set to global mount namespace for SU. after that things started workon several apps that refused to prompt. the app is solid and as good as i remember it from a number of years ago.
google_play_reviews.replyContent: Menu - Show rules -> export to SD / Send error report. without that I can't help.

google_play_reviews.content: Does what it says on the tin. Very well.

AFWall+ is probably one of the most important apps on my phone. I like how I can leave an app's wireless capabilities off by default, essentially sandboxing it before allowing it to access the internet. My primary use case, however, is disabling access to data on my media apps. Without AFWall+, I would have drained all the data on my limited phone plan countless times. Definitely earned my donation, I've saved way more than $5.

I was previously using NetGuard (VPN), but even if  was connected to wifi, after rebooting, I'd still lose about 10 kB of data. And if I wasn't on wifi, several MB would leak after a reboot unless I turned off data. So I bit the bullet and rooted (S6). Now, with AFWall and their data leak fix, I use 0 KB upon reboot while on wifi, and only a tiny amount of KB while on data (whatever data my calling/texting app uses).

I think it's a pretty cool app for blocking other undesired apps' background/foreground data usage. It save me a lot from Google's apps ridiculous wifi data streaming... But the PROBLEM is, it drains battery so much. Maybe it caused by the app countinously blocking so many data in and out, and of course it'll raise up the phone temperature pretty high. At this overheat condition, the battery won't charging normally or need extra time to fill it up. :/ --- (I'm running on ZTE V9820 Kitkat 4.2)
google_play_reviews.replyContent: Disable "Fix starup delay option" from experimental preference. If you see battery drain, try disabling "Active rules" as well.

google_play_reviews.content: Work excellent quietly at background. Very stable never crash. Consume little power. No ads, no nonsense. One of best firewall using iptable, different from many VPN firewall that is unstable. But UI is old. Doesn't show which apps tried to access data like NoRoot Firewall. Doesn't show apps data usage. Overall, excellent.

I have to laugh at anyone that has poorly rated this app.  It uses Linux based iptables.  Linux is one big permissions OS.  You fooshly rooting your phone have taken yourself (user account) out of the virtual machine and into the highest level of access to all your devices hardware, software, and  kernel. You have also given this access to this level of access to apps you've  installed.  Unless you are an advance user, there is  no need for you to have this application or to have access to the Root account. Stick to the simple fake VPN non Root firewalls to save on data.  How this program works in a nutshell is, if you are running a VPN only check off the VPN box for the desired app but do not check any others such as LAN, WIFI, DATA.  The only app you should be giving Access to WiFi and data is the VPN.  This tunnels all the web traffic through the VPN to the selected apps.  If your VPN app crashes then you can rest assure that none of your apps are able to access the internet externally.    As for LAN .  If you don't know don't ever allow an app to have access to it ....iv have been using this app for years and is my favorite app  of on my phone.  Actually, I'm going to purchase the pro version right now.  Thank you
google_play_reviews.replyContent: Thank you for your appreciation.

This is generally an excellent firewall app. I've been using it for a couple of years. Knocked off one star on the rating because it doesn't properly handle root permissions: If the app has been granted root privs previously but the privs are revoked or root functionality has been disabled (ie on LineageOS where root can be turned on/off in developer options) instead of complaining that it can't get root privs the app hangs indefinitely.
